content.text: Measure the mass \(m_{1}\) of measuring cylinder A using the top-pan balance, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Pour approximately \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of sand into **measuring cylinder A**
**The sand is to remain in the measuring cylinder for the rest of the experiment.**
Measure the volume \(V_{1}\) of sand in measuring cylinder A
Measure the mass \(m_{2}\) of measuring cylinder A and the sand using the top-pan balance, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Use your values of \(m_{1}\) and \(m_{2}\) to calculate the mass \(m_{3}\) of the sand
Calculate a value for the density \(\rho_{1}\) of the sand. Use your values from **(a)**(i) and the equation \(\rho_{1} = \frac{m_{3}}{V_{1}}\). Include a unit
Describe **one** possible source of inaccuracy in the measurements taken in **method 1**. You may assume that all measurements are taken carefully and involve good experimental practice

parts.label: (i)

content.text: Pour exactly \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water into **measuring cylinder B**
Pour this water into measuring cylinder A, as shown in Fig. 1.3
Wait until the water level is constant then record the reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in measuring cylinder A

issues: LaTeX superscript (^) found outside math mode
LaTeX superscript (^) found outside math mode

content.text: On Fig. 1.3, draw an arrow showing the correct line of sight for reading the water level in measuring cylinder A
Calculate another value for the density \(\rho_{2}\) of the sand
Use your values from **(a)**(i) and **(b)**(i) and the equation \(\rho_{2} = \frac{m_{3}}{(V_{2} - k)}\), where \(k = 100 \text{cm}^3\)
**Method 2**
Explain why **method 1** would **not** be a suitable method for her to use
Explain why **method 2** would give a more accurate value for the density of the particles in the sample of sand
Another student wants to determine the density of the particles in a sample of sand
In this experiment, you will determine the density of sand by two methods
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.1
Fig. 1.2
Method 1
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into beaker B
Place the thermometer in the water
Measure, and record in the appropriate column heading of Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water.
Remove the thermometer from the water in beaker B
Remove the lid from beaker A
Place beaker A inside beaker B, as shown in Fig. 2.2, so that the water in beaker B rises between the sides of the two beakers
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and replace the lid
Place the thermometer in the water in beaker A
In Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-watch
Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\)
Remove the thermometer and lid from beaker A
Remove beaker A from beaker B and empty both beakers
Pour \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water and \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker B
Place the thermometer in the water
Measure, and record in the appropriate column heading of Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_2\) of the water
Repeat (a)(ii) for this arrangement

content.text: Write a conclusion stating in what way the temperature of the water surrounding beaker A affects the rate of cooling of the hot water in beaker A
Justify your answer by reference to values from your readings
Calculate the average cooling rate \(R\) for beaker A cooling in **cold** water. Use your readings for beaker A from Table 2.1 and the equation

where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{\text{A}0}\) and \(\theta_{\text{A}180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit for the cooling rate
Another student repeats this experiment at the same room temperature
State **one** other variable that she controls in order to obtain readings as close as possible to your readings
During the experiment, the increase in temperature of the water surrounding beaker A affects the results of the investigation
Suggest **one** change to the experiment to reduce this effect
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in surroundings with different temperatures
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1 and Fig. 2.2
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the triangular illuminated object
Place the screen near the lens
Switch on the lamp
Move the screen until a clear focused image of the triangular illuminated object is seen on the screen
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(\nu\) between the lens and the screen
Repeat the procedure for \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\)
Switch off the lamp
Describe a technique to obtain an image on the screen that is as sharp as possible in this experiment
For each distance \(u\), calculate, and record in Table 3.1, a value for \(\frac{u}{V}\)
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{u}{V}\) (x-axis). Start your graph at the origin (0,0)
Draw the best-fit line
Determine the value \(u_{0}\) of \(u\) when \(\frac{u}{V} = 0\)
The gradient of the graph is numerically equal to the focal length \(f\) of the lens
Determine the value of \(f\) for this experiment
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information to determine the gradient
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the brightness of a lamp
Plan an experiment to investigate how the intensity (brightness) of the light produced by the lamp is affected by the current in the lamp
The apparatus available includes:
a lamp and power supply
a light meter which measures the intensity of light arriving at it
an ammeter
a variable resistor
You are **not** required to do this experiment
In your plan, you should:
complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show the variable resistor connected to control the current in the lamp
state the key variables to be kept constant
explain briefly how to do the experiment
draw a table with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
